original_title: Sri Lanka making progress on IMF deal: Minister
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is making progress in an International Monetary Fund agreement but improvements have to be made, State Minister for Finance Shehan Semasinghe said.
Increasing revenues and avenues to strengthen the economy were being explored, he said.
Domestic debt optimization was one of the steps that had to be completed.
“Domestic debt optimization should not be politicized,” Minister Semasinghe said.
Speculative statements made the process more difficult and authorities would ensure that there were no unfair decisions.
Financial sector stability will be ensured and the provident funds will not be impacted negatively, he said. IMF programs was aimed at ensuring stability, he said.
Sri Lanka had the first round of negotiations with bilateral creditors and an initial meeting with private creditors earlier.
“Creditors are showing they want to sort out the debt issues,” Minister Semasinghe said.
Initial discussions with private creditors were cordial and they were positive about Sri Lanka, he said.

An IMF mission was currently in Sri Lanka. The first review under the IMF program is due in September, based on June data. Authorities are hoping to wrap up debt re-structuring by that time. (Colombo/May14/2022)
